description:
...but don't install it from here. Install it manually using the DEB files. I realize this is more difficult, but I've had some issues with the one from the Ubuntu Software app. Specifically it lost my entire library, which isn't a big deal -- the media files were still there -- but I had to re-categorize my files and fix the problematic matches.

Additionally, if you did already install Plex here and you then install Plex from the DEB file, you will have two Plex Media Servers in a race condition!

That being said, once you have your Plex Media Server installed and configured the way you want, you will probably want to buy the lifetime Plex membership. This gives you remote access from anywhere, an SSL cert for your Plex server, and a bunch of other goodies. Worth it and a good way to support the Plex developers.
summary: The best media server by far

description: https://www.plex.tv

I have installed Plex on various linux systems over the years and it always takes a little work. Instead of setting up the Plex repository I used the snap and it worked out of the box. Permissions for folders in home directory worked. Good job!

description:
I have a mounted networked SMB shared directory for Movies and TV Shows.

I successfully installed plexmediaserver using the snap store.

When I added a library I was able to navigate to my shared directories okay but I was receiving errors on plex. 

Eventually I discovered permissions for plexmediaserver in the snap store where the option "Access USB hardware directly" was disabled by default. 

I have plenty of experience mounting usb sticks to create bootable usb so I figured my mounted network drives would be considered the same as USB hardware.

I enabled "Access USB hardware directly" then I had no issues adding library to the network shared directories.
summary: Great App! If adding nfs or cifs to library then enable permission

description: Moving over all my old DVD's and CD's. It plays on PS4, Iphone, Chromecast... Really nice software. Wish they had a plex pass / full version for people not interested in Live TV/ DVR. So far have bought the app to support them instead.

I use this software every day for years.
The remote accesss with plex premium is great when I travel.

Only wished it could have more options in the photo management, like multiple photos selection for download.
summary: Great media player. Been using for years

description: Great for watching movies

After performing a fresh rebuild of my Ubuntu 20.04.2 LTS system for running Plex, I noticed that my system could no longer identify my Hauppauge TV card.
After researching the problem online, I discovered that this appears to be an issue with the SNAP installation method.
After uninstalling from Ubuntu Software, and downloading the .DEB from the Plex website, I was able to get everything working again. Kind of dissapointed that the Ubuntu installer doesn't work for me anymore. I still give 5 stars to the Plex app.
summary: Doesn't support my TV Card, had to work around it

concurrent file transfers to the same USB HDD. Pure Gold!

description: It works great!!

I've used free Plex for 3+ years. It's had a few rough spots with bugs, but are generally fixed within a few days. Current versions have worked great and no issues. I run my Plex server in the background of my laptop and hardly notice any CPU loading when watching content on my TV or phone using the Plex App. Great system - for free!
summary: Awesome media system for whole home

description:
The best media server that I've used.

I run it on a machine with an atom processor, and it performs exceptionally well. 

The software has the ability to transcode on the fly, or optimize video (and store it), in case your player (i.e. old amazon firesticks) don't have the power to play directly.

The name matching engine is pretty good, but if you name the files using the method they describe in their documentation, then it matches the content perfectly and presents posters and descriptions and ratings for the content. 

If you pay for a plex pass, you can even set it up to stream remotely to your browser or mobile device.

Recent convert to Ubuntu when my Mac Mini aged out. Bizarre errors like subtitles/closed captioning going wonky only with ABC shows in the US... stuff that past experience with the forum on plex.tv makes me hesistant to even bring up there.

It works.. mostly. Media sharing is nice when someone misses a show in a different time zone, or there are storms in my area. If not for that, i would be running Channels. All I care about is broadcast TV.
summary: I've used it for years but don't love the support forum

description:
Ah, where do I start???? I've been using PMS for several years now and have a Lifetime Pass to go with it. The servers have an accumulated space of around 50Tb, with TV Shows on one, and Films on the other and both stream to a multitude of devices from the Roku TV and streaming sticks, to Android TV and other devices flawlessly via internal network and over the internet to family.
The server is easy to setup, but the only issue I had was I had to use fstab to get PMS to see my other drives, but this was straightforward and I had it all scanning within 30 mins.
I don't use the hosted media (Plex Live TV & Movies) much myself, but I know family members have and said it works great!!
If you have a large media library as I have, I totally recommend Plex as your one stop media library assistant!!

I'm a lifetime Plex pass holder. I fell in love with the media center 15 years ago when one of the guys behind it was pumping it up on the SomethingAwful forums. It's a little sad that the Plex from 2009 had a hundred times the reach that today's Plex has.

I compare Plex to Launchbox because they serve the same purpose for different media. Launchbox is video games, Plex is TV/movies (+ sub-based music lol + PlutoTV lineup that even my old PSP could get lol). Both offered Lifetime passes in their infancy and I took the bait on both. Launchbox has continually made me grateful for my decision, Plex has not. Launchbox has done nothing but add feature after feature, they are devoted listeners of the community, and they have a clear and transparent vision for the road map of the application. Plex makes most of us nervous because we're not sure if they'll ever fix bug X or Y, if they'll up and decide to axe a long-cherished feature because it could compromise their attractiveness to shareholders down the line. When Plex decided to completely drop support for plugins some years ago, that was the real punch to the gut. They claimed it was a cost and security decision, but we now know that's a hunk of baloney because one of LastPass's devops engineers got hacked in 2020 simply because he didn't update Plex. If outdated versions of Plex are such security risks, why don't they drop support for outdated versions? Makes sense. But nah, they haven't added that to policy.

What keeps me maintaining a Plex server is the few features it does have that none of its competitors have matched (yet), namely smart collections, ease of access, UX, GUI. Configuring Plex is 10/10 on the easy scale when Jellyfin/Emby/Kodi would all fail to hit even a 7. I. Plex feels like a sleek and modern GUI. There's some bugginess with the back button and lag gets pent up sometimes, but I'm still trying to figure out if the remote is to blame GUI and it's super annoying that every other media center looks like its from a PS3/XBox360.
summary: Plex has the polish but none of its competitor's customizability
